Literature Review:
The role of leadership in fostering creativity and innovation within organizations has been a subject of extensive research. Creativity, defined as the generation of novel and useful ideas, is a critical component of innovation, which is the implementation of these ideas into new products, services, or processes (Amabile, 1996). Leaders play a pivotal role in shaping the creative performance of their followers by influencing both their willingness to engage in creative tasks and their ability to solve creative problems. This literature review explores the mechanisms through which leaders impact follower creativity and the implications for leader development. 

One of the primary ways leaders influence creativity is through the establishment of a supportive environment that encourages risk-taking and experimentation. Amabile et al. (2004) emphasize the importance of a work environment that provides autonomy, resources, and encouragement for creativity. Leaders who foster a climate of psychological safety, where followers feel safe to express novel ideas without fear of ridicule or punishment, are more likely to see enhanced creative performance among their teams (Edmondson, 1999). This environment allows followers to engage in creative problem-solving without the constraints of traditional hierarchical structures. 

Transformational leadership, characterized by the ability to inspire and motivate followers towards a shared vision, has been consistently linked to higher levels of creativity and innovation (Bass & Riggio, 2006). Transformational leaders are adept at articulating a compelling vision that aligns with the creative goals of the organization, thereby motivating followers to transcend their self-interests for the sake of the collective good. This type of leadership also involves intellectual stimulation, where leaders challenge assumptions and encourage followers to think critically and creatively (Jung, 2001). 

Moreover, leaders can directly impact follower creativity through their own creative problem-solving skills. Leaders who demonstrate high levels of creative thinking can serve as role models, inspiring their followers to adopt similar approaches to problem-solving (Mumford et al., 2002). This modeling behavior is crucial in setting the tone for what is expected and valued within the organization. Additionally, leaders who actively participate in creative processes can provide valuable feedback and guidance, helping followers refine their ideas and approaches (Zhou & George, 2001). 

The concept of leader-member exchange (LMX) theory also provides insights into how leaders can influence follower creativity. High-quality LMX relationships, characterized by mutual trust, respect, and obligation, have been shown to enhance follower creativity by providing a supportive and resource-rich environment (Graen & Uhl-Bien, 1995). In such relationships, followers are more likely to receive the support and resources needed to pursue creative endeavors, as well as the encouragement to take risks and explore new ideas. 

Furthermore, leaders can impact creativity by facilitating collaboration and knowledge sharing among team members. Cross-functional teams, where diverse perspectives and expertise are brought together, can lead to more innovative solutions (Paulus & Nijstad, 2003). Leaders play a crucial role in orchestrating these interactions, ensuring that team members have the opportunity to share their ideas and build on each other's strengths. This collaborative approach not only enhances creativity at the individual level but also at the team and organizational levels. 

The development of leader thinking skills is essential for fostering creativity within organizations. Training programs that focus on enhancing leaders' creative problem-solving abilities, as well as their capacity to create supportive environments, can have a significant impact on organizational innovation (Puccio et al., 2011). Such programs should emphasize the importance of emotional intelligence, as leaders with high emotional intelligence are better equipped to manage the emotional dynamics of creative work and to foster a positive climate for innovation (Goleman, 1998). 

In conclusion, leaders have a profound impact on the creative performance of their followers through various mechanisms, including the establishment of a supportive environment, transformational leadership, role modeling, high-quality LMX relationships, and facilitation of collaboration. The development of leader thinking skills is crucial for enhancing these capabilities and ultimately driving organizational innovation. Future research should continue to explore the complex interplay between leadership and creativity, with a focus on identifying specific leader behaviors and skills that most effectively promote creative performance.
